identificationModule.briefTitle: A Combined Neurofeedback-TMS Intervention for Alcohol Use Disorder
identificationModule.officialTitle: A Combined Neurofeedback-TMS Intervention for Alcohol Use Disorder

collaborators.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA)

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The goal of this clinical study is to test the effectiveness of a supplemental fMRI neurofeedback and/or TMS intervention in individuals seeking treatment for Alcohol Use Disorder.

After an initial visit, participants will come in once a week for four (4) weeks for an intervention session, which may or may not include TMS and MRI. Participants will be contacted for monthly follow-ups (remotely) for up to 12 months and will be asked to come in for two MRI follow-ups at 6 and 12 months.

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: The PI will prospectively assign treatment groups with blind codes and so will not be blind to treatment type. Other staff, who are the individuals primarily working with the patients and who will be conducting follow-up interviews, will be blind to treatment type. It is not possible to blind the 5th condition (treatment as usual with a brief check-in).

armGroups.label: Neurofeedback-active + TMS-active
armGroups.description: 4 sessions of: TMS (protocol: 10 Hz pulses delivered at 110% of MT in 60 x 5 sec trains with 25 sec ITI) Neurofeedback (protocol: presentation of own brain activity from multiple ROIs measured using fMRI)

armGroups.label: Neurofeedback-active + TMS-sham
armGroups.description: 4 sessions of: TMS (protocol: 10 Hz pulses delivered using the Sham TMS coil in 60 x 5 sec trains with 25 sec ITI) Neurofeedback (protocol: presentation of own brain activity from multiple ROIs measured using fMRI)

armGroups.label: Neurofeedback-sham + TMS-active
armGroups.description: 4 sessions of: TMS (protocol: 10 Hz pulses delivered at 110% of MT in 60 x 5 sec trains with 25 sec ITI) Neurofeedback (protocol: presentation of other's brain activity from multiple ROIs measured using fMRI)
interventionNames: Behavioral: Realtime fMRI Neurofeedback - Yoked Sham

armGroups.label: Neurofeedback-sham + TMS-sham
armGroups.description: 4 sessions of: TMS (protocol: 10 Hz pulses delivered using the Sham TMS coil in 60 x 5 sec trains with 25 sec ITI) Neurofeedback (protocol: presentation of other's brain activity from multiple ROIs measured using fMRI)
interventionNames: Behavioral: Realtime fMRI Neurofeedback - Yoked Sham

armGroups.label: Check-In Only
armGroups.description: 4 sessions of: Completing typical pre-TMS/MRI procedures Being prompted to reflect on outside treatment (TAU)

interventions.name: Realtime fMRI Neurofeedback - Active
interventions.description: fMRI aided reinforcement of craving regulation

interventions.name: TMS - Active
interventions.description: rTMS to right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex to reduce craving

interventions.name: Realtime fMRI Neurofeedback - Yoked Sham
interventions.description: Display of feedback from other participant's sessions to serve as a sham for fMRI aided reinforcement of craving regulation

interventions.name: TMS - Sham
interventions.description: rTMS using placebo coil (no brain stimulation, emulates other features of active TMS), placed over right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Alcohol Use over Time
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessed at weeks: 1 (baseline), 2-5 (intervention sessions, pre and post), 9, 13, 17, 21, 25, 33, 37, 41, 45, 49, 53 (follow-ups)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Alcohol Craving over Time
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessed at weeks: 1 (baseline), 2-5 (intervention sessions, pre and post), 9, 13, 17, 21, 25, 33, 37, 41, 45, 49, 53 (follow-ups)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Community Functioning over Time
Change in Employment Status over Time
Change in Aggression and Victimization over Time
Change in Antisocial Behavior over Time
primaryOutcomes.description: number of self-reported contacts with the police, convictions, and other criminal behaviors

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Brain Activity during Alcohol Cue Presentation over Time
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via fMRI; standard alcohol cue reactivity
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessed at weeks: 1 (baseline), 5 (post final intervention), 29 and 57 (follow-ups)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Brain Activity during Simultaneous Sociomoral & Alcohol Cue Presentation over Time
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via fMRI; alcohol-cued sociomoral processing
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Assessed at weeks: 1 (baseline), 5 (post final intervention), 29 and 57 (follow-ups)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Brain Gray Matter Structure over Time
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measured via MRI; gray matter volume

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Brain White Matter Structure over Time
secondaryOutcomes.description: Measured via MRI; white matter diffusion

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Resting State Functional Connectivity over Time

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Age 19-65
2. Receiving treatment for Alcohol Use Disorder

Exclusion Criteria:

1. MRI Contraindications

   1. Presence of metal in the body that would make having a 7T MRI unsafe (including facial tattoos)
   2. Claustrophobia, such that individual would be unable to stay in the MRI for up to 1 hr
   3. Hearing loss, including tinnitus, that might be made worse by MRI or TMS
2. TMS Contraindications

   1. Has ever had a seizure, or has a family history of epilepsy
   2. Taking medications or substances that lower the seizure threshold
   3. Implanted devices that are in the head or rely on physiological signals
   4. History of neurological disease, such as stroke or brain tumor
   5. Head injury with loss of consciousness greater than 30 minutes
   6. Actively withdrawing from alcohol
3. Family history of schizophrenia or presence of psychotic symptoms

ipdSharingStatementModule.description:
Data will be shared within the NIAAA Data Archive according to the standard data sharing plan. Deidentified individual data regarding the outcome variables (clinical and MRI) will be included. Participants will have the option to opt out of sharing their individual data.

Given the highly sensitive and confidential nature of the information, and the magnitude of potential harms to participants associated with disclosure, clinical outcome data pertaining to criminal acts and illegal activities will not be available in the data repository.
